pullRequest.body:
The Faa di Bruno formula expresses `D^n (g o f)` in terms of the iterated derivatives of `g` and `f`. The hardest part of the formalization is probably just being able to express the formula. This PR deals with the combinatorial prerequisites for the proof of the formula, defining ordered finpartitions of `Fin n` and showing how an ordered finpartition of `Fin (n+1)` can be built out of an ordered finpartition of `Fin n`.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

Thanks for the review! I merged all your comments, excepted for two that I reverted because I didn't understand how to fix things.

Looks great, thank you!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11669554152/job/32491760072)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11669554152/job/32491759452)
Thanks for the great work! I don't seem to be able to golf much past the cosmetics 😅

I don't know the details of the analysis here, but to give this bijection and define an ordered partition in the way that you describe, the implementation choices in OrderedFinpartition certainly aren't the ones that are natural to combinatorics in Lean. Could you say something about the choices made there? For instance, why parametrise by the greatest element? Why is it more useful to index by Fin rather than an arbitrary fintype? Why is it useful to index at all? There was a lot of discussion about indexing in finpartition when that was new - for instance because a naive translation of what's written informally suggests that indexing there would be useful, but the formalisation is significantly more convenient by avoiding explicit indexes. Can you say why indexing is necessary in this particular case?

Yes, it's definitely an unusual implementation. The reason is really that it's the one I need for the Faa di Bruno formula. The formula reads as follows (mixing math and Lean, but hopefully this should be clear) :
```
D^n (g o f) (x) (v_0, ..., v_{n-1}) = \sum_{c : OrderedFinpartition n}, 
  D^c.length g (f x, fun (i : Fin c.length) -> D^(c.partSize i) f (v o c.emb i))
```
So, you can see that the `OrderedFinpartition` shows up through the embeddings `c.emb`. The formula is only true if the parts are ordered by increasing maxima (in the general situation where the iterated derivatives are not symmetric a priori). And in the inductive proof of the formula, what matters is how the embeddings correspond to each other when one extend the finpartition by adding an atom to the left, hence the implementation of `extendEquiv` which builds this with nice defeqs.

I don't expect this very specific implementation can be used for anything else than the Faa di Bruno formula, which is why I have left it in this file instead of creating a new file in the `Combinatorics` folder. You can have a look at https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17152/files to see how the completed file looks like, and how the implementation is used in the inductive proof of the formula.

I see, that makes sense. Could you add your second paragraph - or something similar to it - to the implementation notes in this file? Similarly it might be nice to add to the docstring of OrderedFinpartition saying that it is only intended to be used for this formula, to prevent future contributors being confused.

My only remaining worry is that the implementation details of OrderedFinpartition may need to be exposed to people using the Faa di Bruno formula, since as you say, the formula genuinely uses the embeddings it contains, but it looks like your `taylorComp` abstraction hides this nicely?

I have expanded the docstrings (both file-level and of the structure) to explain the design, and how specific it is.

For my application, it is indeed not necessary to look at the details of ordered finpartitions, the API is hiding this nicely. For other applications, it could be useful to have a bound on the cardinality of ordered finpartitions, and for that constructing the equiv with usual Finpartitions will be useful. But I'd say this can wait until someone needs it.
Is this analogous to the partitions found in #16647, applied to `finRange`?

Yes, definitely. It looks like the order you get on sublists is even the same one as the one I need here, i.e., parts are ordered by increasing maximum. This is not so surprising because I need these to do an induction from the left (i.e., the leftmost point plays a specific role), and in your case of lists you define things by induction from the left.

For instance, for `n = 2`, there are 2 partitions of `{0, 1}`, given by `{0}, {1}` and `{0, 1}`,
```

```

`OrderedFinpartition n` and the equivalence between
```

```

```

```

```

```

```suggestion
  emb := Fin.cases (fun _ ↦ 0) (Fin.tail ∘ c.emb)
```
This one doesn't seem correct (`succ` takes a guy with index in `Fin n`, and creates a guy with index in `Fin (n + 1)`, while `tail` does the opposite), so I reverted this one.
Ah sorry composition is on the wrong side

```

Given that you start all your proofs of this field with `eq_univ_of_forall`

```

```
here and below

          (cases (motive := fun _ ↦ Fin (n + 1)) 0 (tail <| c.emb m)) b' by
```
and everywhere else

Fixed, thanks!
Given that you are only using this in `extendEquiv`, why not inline it? This is what you do for the `erase` side
It's for the way I use it in the sequel. You can have a look at #17400 if you want: `c.extend i` shows up a lot of times.
